My expectations were low. I knew because it was an idle game that not everything about it would be super smooth, and that's totally fine. But it's completely worse than what I had imagined, and what I would call un-usable at the moment. Having the correct number of ducks, having the few keys that exist work, and not having the game somehow run when it's closed are all things I just can't accept. 


Not a lot of explanation as to what is supposed to happen, which caused a lot of headache at the start. I believe when two ducks touch, they turn into a duck they've touched? It made me think one of my ducks went missing. And one of my ducks a separate time actually Did go missing. As in I had 5 ducks then suddenly I only had 4 and could only tab through 4 ducks total. I never figured out why. Also, while I am glad the controls cheat-sheet is easy to find again, it doesn't cover every key you need to play (or I got completely glitched, as I never actually found a solution). For example, I put the camera into a chair to watch the ducks from the chair, and I could not get out of the chair no matter what key I clicked or anything. I don't remember exactly how I got out of it, but I think an achievement went off or something special that just unlocked the camera for me because I remember suddenly the camera was on a specific duck and after that I could tab through them like normal. (Whatever it was, it was different than the aesthetic AFK video because it stayed on this one duck until I manually moved to the next duck, where the AFK video moves camera positions a lot.)

Also, definitely glitchy! Both visual glitches, which are acceptable, but not helping its case. But also keys not working correctly. And, the game-breaker for me was the music randomly started playing 20 hours after I last played! The game was not open at all (I had closed out of it completely using the 'save and quit' or whatever equivalent button there was in-game. The game wasn't in Task Manager when I looked after the music started, and I know for certain it was Closed, not just minimized)! I had to force Steam closed and restart the computer to make the music shut off! Not only did it terrify me, but it's simply not acceptable to have my normal day be interrupted by at random by a game that's not even open.

I genuinely loved this game. While there isn't much to do, I loved having it just be on my computer so there's something shown so when I walk back into my room after leaving the house I can just see a bunch of silly ducks on the screen. If you care for puzzles, there are secrets to this game! I however don't care for puzzles much, so look that up on YouTube if you want those haha. I'd say this game is mainly just a nice thing to leave playing on your screen when you're doing something else and not actively using your computer.

For any achievement hunters, be warned! You will just be leaving the game open and HOPING for hours that you get an achievement you're working towards, as I did. LOL.  

It is a great and silly little game though, Highly suggest. :)

See my profile for more details about my reviews.

Additional notes: can't believe I will add to the Overwhelmingly Positive bandwagon... but yeah, I can't really downvote it either. I have to be very clear though: understand that this is NOT a game. This is not a video game, this is... art. Not in its purest form, but it definitely is some kind of art installation you would find at a museum from a hipster artist, with some clever (but a bit pretentious) ideas in it, for sure... but this is not a video game, you will not PLAY it, make sure of that before buying. This is a glorified screensaver. And while I would roll my eyes at that in a museum, as a virtual/digital creation? I get the idea... it's very cute and tongue in cheek funny. Often it is hard with these hipster creations to know the limit between making fun of something/not taking yourself seriously... and actually being/doing it for real. I would have honestly wished for MUCH, MUCH more interaction between the ducks, like making EACH of them unique in their sound, their action, their interaction etc. Waiting for a ufo abduction or a punctured flamingo felt somehow underwhelming after so many hours of patience...
So, as it is? meh, it's ok, after 12 hours letting it run, I am fine. Might buy the dlcs one day if they make a sale at 1 buck the whole thing, as a symbolic gesture towards the effort of making it... but that is about it. Fine! Take your thumbs up and go, I have real games to play now.

In total I spent $8 on this game, And I do not regret it.

When I first got this game I thought it was a very simple game: collect a few ducks float around and that's it. however as my ducks slowly grew larger and larger and I acquired more and more. I then started looking around and realized that this world of the Ducks that we choose to be a part of is more than just some plastic ducks floating on a pool. It was a Great Awakening of sorts and I have devoted my time and effort to obtaining every duck physically possible. I never thought that they'll be such Connections in this game that take a spiritual and deeper meaning into oneself and the understanding that the Ducks are the reason we are all here today and that without the Placid plastic ducks I would have never experienced such greatness such as exploding ducks, fire ducks, burning ducks, Ducks being put out by other ducks, ducks flying and getting themselves stuck in a place that I didn't even know was possible, and of course duck. With that being said, What I  originally thought was a waste of $8 was $8 well spent.

I bought it just as a joke - now I imagine I'll have to get the DLCs to get more ducks... MORE !  I must have MORE DUCKS !!

(It's like having a fish tank - that you don't have to clean, and the fish are ducks...)

So, I started the game. Yellow duck spawns.
It drifts towards the slide. It looks like a good time, a nice adventure.

EVERYTHING GOES SOUTH.

The current is too strong! My poor duck is thrown over the edge and rolls under the chair sitting off to the right. I proceeded to name the duck "Sad". That duck sat under that chair for the whole session that day.

Since then, the ducks live in my head rent free. As they drift around, and gather together, I form my own little narratives between the ducks... they take on a life of their own...

Okay, when I saw this game on sale I was like... Hmm, collectathon duck game... Never played these sorts of games before, and I wasn't sure if I'd like it, but I bought it anyway since it's under 2 euros and saw a lot of positive reviews. 

The reviews were not joking. This game is genuinely brilliant. It's surprisingly intricate, there were a lot of unexpected reactions and events between the ducks that made this game so much funnier and enjoyable. Bought it for my boyfriend instantly as well so we can AFK collect rubber ducks together. It's great to leave this game just play in the background, do it's own thing, let UFO's steal your ducks, or the ducks fly off on their own into the ocean while you do something else. There is surprisingly a lot of attention to detail.

The graphics are great, ambient is really good, and the ducks are absolutely adorable.

10/10 get it for yourself even if it's not on sale. I genuinely love this game. 
P.S. My propeller hat duck and submarine duck flew away. I miss them.

This game has, frankly, changed my outlook on life. I went from simply existing in my world, taking everything for granted and letting life pass me by, too actually stopping and observing what was going on around me. The grass blowing in the wind, the local wildlife as they go about living life. I watched them live a lifestyle I had long forgotten about. One of enjoyment and tranquillity. One I still, deep down, longed for. This game helped me not only come to this understanding, but come this much closer to actually experiencing it. This game has absolutely changed my outlook on life for the better, and I have preached this game to everybody I know like gospel. Needless to say, this game is a 10/10. I cannot thank the developers of this game nearly enough for the amazing experience they have crafted. Please buy this game for yourself and everybody you know. I promise you will not regret it.

If you want to avoid avoid mild gameplay spoilers, I will tell you that this game is truly 17.9287/10 and fully deserves to be game of the year. However, if you don't mind spoilers, allow me to tell you the fully true story of "the rescue mission."

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Once upon a time, in a pool, there placidly floated several plastic ducks. These ducks were especially placid that day, as the yellow ducky Tomathan had recently given birth to three beautiful children: Unnamed Child 1, Unnamed Child B, and Unnamed Child 4. One day, however, Tomathan visited the private pool. Whether it was for a business meeting, to visit family, simply a vacation, or something else entirely, we simply don't know. However, we do know that he left his children in the upper pool. This is when something utterly horrible occurred. Despite the disco ball duck's best attempt to block it, the natural enemy of the plastic duck, the flamingo floatie, had entered the pool... Right on top of the children! This would have caused all three to be captured in the flamingo's donut shaped center, had the leopard duck not launched itself from the tube slide at the children just in time to knock two out of the way. However, one was left behind. When Tomathan returned to discover one of his children trapped, he was understandable horrified. He tried to free his child be nudging the flamingo, but that only made things worse, as he caused the floatie to block the slide to the private pool. Withing minutes, every single duck was in the upper, public pool, crowding it to they point that they could hardly move. Yet, amidst the chaos, a hero arose: Knife duck. Knife duck, using his mystical power of... knife, was able to pop the flamingo duck, not only saving the child, but the entire community! And so, while the ducks could never return to their placid ways, as they had never left their placid ways, they did become slightly less overcrowded. The end!
This game changed my life, it is one of the most spectacular games in history, and it literally solved all of my problems and helped solve world hunger and boredom. WOULD RECOMMEND

I'm not particularly a completionist when it comes to video games, nor have I ever really felt the need to be-- but when I randomly installed this game on impulse a few days ago, something happened to me. I went into some sort of duck-induced trance. I spent a solid couple of days playing this game, attempting to solve puzzles and easter eggs in a frenzied state, translating morse code and god knows what else to try and unlock what this game has going on. I made a spreadsheet so I could more accurately keep track of which ducks had spawned. I've never 100%ed a game so fast in my LIFE. and somehow, despite feeling as though i was descending further and further into madness with each new duck, I enjoyed every second of it.

[h1]Overall Impressions[/h1]
Not so much a "game" as it is an idle collect-athon. However there are several secrets throughout offering a surprising amount mystery. It's a relaxing game to have on in the background. 

[h1]What I Liked[/h1]
I got addicted to uncovering and naming each and every duck. The design of many ducks was really creative and each offered something of a gimmick. For instance, the magma duck would set nearby things ablaze while the firefighter duck would spew water around and put out fires. It was fun uncovering what each could do. 

The music was chill and relaxing. 

[h1]What Could Be Improved[/h1]
I floundered with the camera controls at first. There are very limited options to interact with the game world. You basically can just tab between available ducks or 2 -3 fixed view spots for each location. The mouse has to be "unlocked" in order to click on anything. Controller support was negligible. 

[h1]Final Thoughts & Rating[/h1]
It's a very relaxing experience listening to the music and collecting new ducks. Usually I'd play this while doing other things. But it's pretty much a lightly interactive screensaver. I'd only recommend if your into achievement hunting or idle collection based games.

This game was already an insanely addictive experience to have by myself, but showing it to my friends (with zero context) via Discords live streaming services led to a 5+ hour long roller coaster of emotions for everyone in the voice call. We named every duck, we created lore for all the events, we laughed at every easter egg, and we cried as propeller duck disappeared into the great beyond. Everytime someone new entered the vc, they would always ask "soooo, whats the objective in this game?" and we'd all ask "is this not enough?" They eventually stopped asking questions and joined us in the hype of this game! Some of my friends even bought the game and live streamed their own perspectives in the same call!

I will definitely be playing more of this silly, peaceful, and addictive game, and you know I will be buying the DLC's! The only reason I haven't bought them yet is because I was too busy watching ducks! Silly reviews and memes aside, this game was super enjoyable and I recommend it to anyone and everyone!

ü¶Ü Quack-tastically Quirky Quackventure! ü¶Ü

As a connoisseur of fine feathered entertainment, I must admit I was initially skeptical about Placid Plastic Duck Simulator. I mean, a game centered around a plastic duck? But let me tell you, dear puddle companions, this game has completely flipped my webbed world upside down ‚Äì in the best possible way!

From the moment I waddled into the virtual pond, I was greeted by a symphony of cheerful quacks and a stunning plastic paradise that would make even the most aloof mallard weak in the knees. The attention to detail is bill-tastic; every ripple on the water's surface, every leaf that floats by, it's all so eerily reminiscent of my real pond, yet delightfully surreal.

The gameplay, my fellow flappers, is where the magic truly happens. I've never experienced such a heart-pounding adrenaline rush as I did when I engaged in the daring pursuit of plastic insect consumption. The physics of nibbling on those crunchy critters are astonishingly accurate ‚Äì I felt like I was truly feasting on the finest digital delicacies.

And let's not overlook the social dynamics at play. The way I smoothly glided across the water, striking up conversations with fellow plastic waterfowl, was a triumph of digital duck diplomacy. Whether we were discussing the latest pond gossip or competing in the Quacklympics (yes, you read that right), every interaction left me feeling like the suavest duck in the pixelated pond.

In conclusion, Placid Plastic Duck Simulator has transformed my perception of gaming. It's not just a game, it's a quack-tastic journey of self-discovery, social bonding, and the pursuit of the ultimate plastic duck enlightenment. So, fellow webbed wanderers, if you're ready to dive headfirst into the most audaciously absurd and feather-ruffling experience of your life, grab your virtual beak and join me in the extraordinary world of Placid Plastic Duck Simulator! ü¶ÜüéÆ

My only gripes are that there's no way to interact directly with any particular duck. It's so frustrating to see a duck just laying on the deck because it got yeeted by one of the mechanisms out of the water. Why can't I pick up the duck and put it back in the water? Is that really such a huge ask? (That brings to mind the stone ducks‚ÄîI wish I could set them gently on the side, or in a shallow area so they weren't just stuck on the bottom the whole time.)
I do also wish there was a free cam option, so I could just look around without orbiting a single duck and then colliding with the deck and zooming in uncontrollably.
I also am a little puzzled by the choice of a manual save mechanic. AFAIK the only thing being saved is the number and types of ducks unlocked on the level, so it seems a bit odd that it requires a manual save. I would expect that as soon as a new duck spawns, the save could be refreshed automatically. It's not like there's an obscene number of variables that need their state stored to reproduce a massive world state (like Skyrim or such).

Gripes aside, the game is enjoyable, particularly for passing time. The unique duck sounds are a treat (though I feel this aspect was not fully "realized"). The sheer variety of designs is impressive and I look forward to collecting even more ducks until there's not a drop of water left not occupied by a duck.

[h1] This is a game about watching plastic ducks float around in a pool. [/h1]

[i] That's it... [/i]

But it's actually not, because it is [b] so much more [/b]. 

This isn't just a game, [i] this is an experience [/i], one of zen tranquillity unlike any you have experienced before. 
Watch the duckies -- one might bump into another! [b] Rude! [/b] Others might be mischievous or naughty, or just plain quirky. 
The ducks socialise in their own placid way, and there's always something going on.
Day changes into night, with it bringing a serene, calm atmosphere, but the duckies don't go to sleep - they are always there to soothe you! The troubles of everyday life drown in the pool as the duckies quack and float on by. [i] Quack quack... [/i] :smileduck:

So if you crave the most tranquil, relaxing experience, don't wait -- join the duckies! 
Be a patient, placid duckling! 

[b] Just remember: flamingos are friends!! [/b] :menacingduck:

Honestly this game is one of the best walking simulator/mmo/rogue-like I've ever seen or played

As a Souls-like game, it revolutionised the genre and it cured my generational cancer.

It made me experience every kind of emotion that ever existed since the birth of human kind. This game is truly a master piece and deserves to be the Number 1 best seller in the history of Steam.

The fact that this game is only 3$ and can rivalize some AAA games like Peggle shows that the creators really took time and developed this game and the environment that can be explored through countless hours of playtime. 

At first glance, Placid Plastic Duck Simulator might seem absurd‚Äîcontrolling a plastic duck in various settings sounds like an odd concept. However, it is precisely this unique premise that sets the game apart from others in the genre. The initial moments of gameplay are surprisingly enjoyable, and it's easy to get immersed in the role of a floating plastic duck in a serene pond or bustling city fountain. The mechanics  of this game might seem simple to grasp to the unfamiliar eye, however, they are surprisingly deep and complex for someone colourblind or a League Of Legends player.

This game offered me salvation from my dark past, it cured my racism and helped me develop a functioning brain as-well as human decency. It made me learn what a shower was and it truly turned my life around for the better. 

In conclusion,  i recommend this game because it's better that rehab and the fog is coming. Enjoy your time.

Edit: I forgot to tell you about the deep lore this game contains. Honestly there are pages upon pages of lore and it's so captivating and intriguing.It distracted me from the voices in my head and now i'm saving 50$ of schizophrenia meds every week. Beware however, you might forget that time flows and end up 7 years into the future without realising. I suggest playing with consideration and carefully watching the time. Also the party duck is a terrorist nothing anyone says can change that fact

[h1] Placid Plastic Duck [/h1]
[hr]
[code] It would be greatly appreciated if you would rate this review with a prize, although it is not necessary. If you want to read more reviews like this follow me as a mentor. If you want to discuss the reviews and talk to other people in my Steam group. The links: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43972666/] My Mentor Page [/url] [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/GuacamoleCenterENG] My Group Page [/url] [/code]

This game is a misunderstood gem that currently needs to get the recognition it deserves.

But you may wonder, why is it supposedly so good? Well, then I will answer your question. Placid Plastic Duck is about some ducks in a swimming pool and it's true, this may seem very boring, but that would only be judging a book by its cover.

In the game you start with a duck in the pool, you will not be able to move it, since it moves by itself and you will only be able to see it from outside or get in the first person, after a while every few minutes another duck will arrive and another and another... Until you have more ducks than days in the sun.

In Placid Plastic Duck you can fulfill your fantasy of having a gigantic number of ducks, being able to have them of different rarities, patterns and colors, in addition to the fact that there are some that can interact with each other and this not only happens with the ducks from the base game, but also with those of the dlcs.

As an experienced player with all the achievements I have witnessed many interactions, there is a duck with a candle that can burn an ice cube to unlock an easter duck (sorry for the joke) and yes, you read that right, there are SECRET ducks, there are several ducks that They can be obtained in the normal map and other secrets that are from the other dlc map, like these there are many interactions, such as a ninja duck that you have to find hidden or a duck that has to capture a ghost duck on camera.

Placid Plastic Duck are not just ducks, they are THE ducks you want to have, you have many types and each one can be more or less to your liking, this game accompanied by its own music can help you relax while you study or finish a job, this game , is what YOU NEED.

As many of reviews already said, this is pretty much Screensaver the game. Save for some achievements/duck, there is no input required - in fact, all you can do is just watch ducks. Some of ducks do have special interaction if you use Quack button, but that's it.

That being said however, it's honestly one of most games I find easy to chill to, hell I like having it on background as I browse internet and talking with people. It's fun to see what ducks are up to. Like a duck wielding a knife who blew up the puddle toy, a duck that's on fire (I named it "I'M ON FIRE") and... yeah. It's cute.

At the asking price I thought it was great value. Just keep in mind there's little to no gameplay but if the idea of watching ducks floating around sounds nice, then I can recommend it.

This game is not really a game. I get that that's the point, but I still thought there would be a little something to do other than  just look at ducks. The only way to get other very simple gameplay elements is by purchasing the DLC which I don't think is worth it. This DLC is not much more than cosmetics required to get all of the achievements which is always very scummy in my opinion. Overall, it's incredibly boring, and I definitely don't recommend it even for the very small price tag.

This game fucking changed my life

I cannot stop playing this incredible game. It has become a permanent fixture in my life, an obsession that has captured my heart and mind. From the very first quack, I was mesmerized by the charming simplicity and whimsical nature of the gameplay. The moment those feathered protagonists dropped onto the screen, I was hooked. And from that point on, my existence was forever transformed.

The world of the Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is a wonderland of creativity, filled with vibrant landscapes, cunning challenges, and delightful surprises around every corner. The attention to detail is astonishing, making each level a captivating work of art. The game consistently delivered moments of pure exhilaration.

But it's not just the gameplay that makes Placid Plastic Duck Simulator utterly captivating‚Äîit's the characters themselves. Each duck has a unique personality that shines through, making them more than just pixels on the screen. They became my companions, my confidants, and, dare I say, my friends. The way they quack and flutter their wings, the mischievous glint in their eyes‚Äîit's impossible not to fall in love with their infectious charm.

This game has taken over my life in the best possible way. It has become my sanctuary, a place where I can escape the trials and tribulations of reality and dive headfirst into a world of joy and laughter. Time loses all meaning as I immerse myself in the game, and before I know it, hours have flown by, leaving me begging for more. The addictive nature of the game is both a blessing and a curse, but it's a price I'm willing to pay for the sheer euphoria it brings.

But what truly sets this game apart from the rest is the emotional impact it has had on me. It's not just a game; it's a transformative experience. It has ignited a fire within me, reminding me of the importance of embracing childlike wonder and finding joy in the simplest of things. The game has taught me valuable life lessons about perseverance, friendship, and the power of a quack-filled adventure.

The visuals and audio of this game are a feast for the senses. The colorful, vibrant environments immerse me in a world that feels alive and brimming with whimsy. The soothing melodies and delightful sound effects create a harmonious symphony that accompanies every quack and jump. It's a sensory experience that transports me to a realm where imagination knows no bounds.

The developers of Placid Plastic Duck Simulator have crafted a masterpiece that goes beyond mere entertainment. It has the power to touch your soul and evoke a wide range of emotions. As I guided my plastic ducks through various challenges, I found myself laughing, cheering, and even shedding a tear or two. The game's ability to elicit such genuine emotional responses is a testament to its brilliance.

One of the aspects that I appreciate most about this game is its ability to capture the essence of childhood innocence. It takes me back to a time when life was simpler, and the smallest things could bring immense joy. The Placid Plastic Duck Simulator reminds us all to cherish the child within us and relish the magic that surrounds us every day.

Beyond its enchanting gameplay and captivating characters, Placid Plastic Duck Simulator also boasts an engaging storyline that kept me on the edge of my seat. The narrative unfolds with surprising depth, exploring themes of love, loss, and personal growth. It's a rare gem in the gaming world, where storytelling often takes a backseat. I was genuinely invested in the fate of the ducks and found myself emotionally invested in their journey.

The sense of community fostered by Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is truly heartwarming. The game's online features allow players from all walks of life to come together and share their experiences. I've made friendships that transcend borders and cultures, all united by our shared passion for these delightful virtual ducks. The game has become a catalyst for connection and has shown me the beauty of forging bonds through a shared love for a digital world.

In an industry that sometimes prioritizes graphics and technical prowess over substance, Placid Plastic Duck Simulator stands tall as a reminder that it's the intangible qualities that truly matter. It's a testament to the power of storytelling, the impact of immersive gameplay, and the ability of a simple plastic duck to touch our hearts.

This is not a game. To me, Placid Plastic Duck Simulator represents the very essence of life itself. In every duck you see, there is personality, individuality, and perhaps even aspirations. Yet, in their buoyant existence they find futility: unable to choose their destination, forever surrendered to the elements. We watch over them like deities indulging in the mysteries of their futures. In spite of life's indifference and disconnect from our influence, they float along. From slipping down a slide to being abducted by UFOs, their rubber remains resilient from the wake of their existence. They float along, no matter what. From their journey, we can derive what it means to be alive: to press on against the waves that crash against us, continuing on in spite of however cruel the world around us is or however lost we are. We are here. We are alive and in the now, to see our own paths follow through wherever they lead. Thus, we can find solace in solemnity. This is not a game. This is a mirror into the soul.

Do you like ducks? Do you REALLY like ducks? Do you like ducks so much you feel like Tari from the SMG4 series? Do you have things like Autism or Adhd (like I do)? If you answered yes to any or all of these questions, you should get this game as soon as possible, you are missing out.

This game is very simplistic, but is very enjoyable and has a quite chill atmosphere. It's basically a screen-saver, but highly engrossing with the excitement of random events, interactions, and seeing what the next duck will be. In addition, the game has a plethora of DLCs and events which, for the fair and perhaps even cheap price of free to $3, add new ducks and new interactions. Overall, an 11/10 game with very nice music and surprisingly entertaining.

Despite this I have no regrets, for a couple of bucks its a fun time waster. Duck on!

This game is fun to just sit in the pool with friends and talk. See what ducks spawn in... but one major issue. Most of us have very good gaming pc's used for streaming most the time... so  why is it that this game uses anywhere from 70%-90% of our GPU according to task manager and other 3rd party spec checkers. Is this game just poorly optimized, or is it running a data miner in the background. To anyone who has lower end pcs, be careful and check your useage/temps, because if this game will use 70-90% of my 2080ti and making it run hot, the "680" minimum requirement might end out overheating.

One of the most unoptimized games I've ever played. No exaggeration, I have DOOM Eternal in my library and even with its state-of-the-art graphics and crappy DRM, it still manages to run better than this game. 

My Steam Deck can run DOOM Eternal at 900p at around 50-40 FPS, meanwhile this game struggles to run 720p @ 30 FPS. No doubt this is partially due to the fact that it has NO graphics settings other than resolution and v-sync. No shadows, water detail, anti-aliasing, post-processing, no settings like that, and it seems the game is just capped at Ultra settings. 

Furthermore, it even runs the CPU hard. HOW? You don't even play the game, it's basically an advanced screensaver. What is the CPU [i]doing[/i]? Are the physics that advanced? Is it running 500 iterations per frame? It's inexcusable, really.

I wanna like this game because it is charmingly simple and not very expensive, but when neither of my computers can run the game at a good resolution at even 30 FPS, it doesn't matter how little the game costs, it's not worth it. If this game gets heavy optimization updates I'll consider picking it up again, but unless that happens, this game would have just be rotting in my library, never to be played again.

If all the games to almost make me cry I didn‚Äôt think placid plastic duck simulator would be one
The sheer unbridled joy that I just feel playing something so calm, peaceful and inoffensive for so long feels so good. Seeing these beautiful, beasts doing nothing but being placid plastic ducks in the water is so beautiful to me. They serve no purpose but to make you smile. They are just plastic ducks floating around in a pool in the middle of nowhere, but that‚Äôs all they need to be. I can‚Äôt explain why, but this came just makes me so emotional. These are just creatures living their lives, floating around on an endless pool and it‚Äôs beautiful. I am overcome with emotion I don‚Äôt fully understand. Like watching a movie you don‚Äôt understand but it makes you cry‚Ä¶ you can‚Äôt fully make sense of it, all you know is that it makes you feel so good.
Especially after how much time I‚Äôve sunk into games like just cause 3, GTA V, GTA online and Fallout 4, it‚Äôs just so jarringly calming to play something with no guns, no action, no drugs, no violence, no objectives, just sitting and smiling in a void of placid plastic ducks floating with no destination in mind.

It‚Äôs cold. It should be cold, but I can‚Äôt feel anything. A flurry of snow rains down around me as I slide across a frozen pool.

A Zamboni without a driver pushes past me, moving the others to the gondola lift. I do not know if it chose to ignore me or if it just missed. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll ever know. 

There‚Äôs a lot of things I‚Äôll never know. Who I am, for example. I know what I am, but I don‚Äôt know what I look like. I‚Äôm a duck, a rubber duck to be exact. The others are too‚Äîthey slide past me, sometimes float past me, if we‚Äôre in water‚Äîand they wear all sorts of colors and designs.

All I know for certain is that I quack sometimes, seemingly at random. I can‚Äôt control it; it just happens.

I don‚Äôt think the others are aware, like I am. I think I‚Äôm the only one who‚Äôs really here. In a sense, I‚Äôm alone...and yet I‚Äôm not. 

Someone else is here. It‚Äôs not one of the ducks. It‚Äôs something else entirely, a different sort of entity. They‚Äôve never done anything to any of us, but I sense their presence. I know they‚Äôre here. I can feel them. But all they do is watch. 

Am I happy with this life? I can‚Äôt say. I can‚Äôt remember anything else. As far as I know, I‚Äôve always been a rubber duck.

It could be worse. Some of the others catch fire. Some of them fly off the mountain, never to be seen again. I‚Äôve even seen one explode. Me? I just float endlessly, without a care in the world. Nothing to do. No need for food. For money. 

But it could be better. If there was just one other duck here, aware, like I am... Would that be better? Would it be better to have someone like me, even if we couldn‚Äôt communicate? I guess I‚Äôll never know.

It‚Äôs getting dark. Darker than nighttime, that is. So dark that I can‚Äôt see, not even the warm glow of fire that is always burning. But this is normal.

The other presence fades. The ducks remain. 

I am alone.

Placid Plastic Duck Simulator has shattered all expectations and redefined what it means to be immersed in a video game. From the very moment I embarked on this extraordinary journey, I was transported to a realm of tranquility and contemplation unlike any other. In this review, I humbly attempt to convey the profound impact this game has had on my life.

Placid Plastic Duck Simulator offers an unprecedented gaming experience by defying conventional controls and embracing the simplicity of being a floating plastic duck. At first glance, one might question the absence of traditional gameplay mechanics. However, it is precisely this absence that allows the true essence of the game to shine through.

From the very first moment, as I gracefully floated on the serene surface of the virtual pond, a profound sense of peace washed over me. The absence of controls brought a newfound freedom, untethering my spirit from the constraints of traditional gaming conventions. As I glided effortlessly through the digital water, I was unburdened by objectives or tasks, and instead, I surrendered myself to the captivating beauty of my surroundings.

The attention to detail in Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is simply astonishing. The meticulously crafted environments, filled with lush vegetation and shimmering sunlight, create an enchanting atmosphere that embraces players in a cocoon of serenity. Each ripple, each subtle reflection, and every gentle breeze contribute to an immersive symphony of tranquility.

One might question the longevity of a game without traditional goals, but Placid Plastic Duck Simulator possesses an everlasting allure. Every session reveals new discoveries and invites profound introspection. The game acts as a mirror, encouraging players to reflect upon their own lives, desires, and the simplicity of being. It serves as a gentle reminder to slow down, appreciate the present moment, and find solace in the beauty that surrounds us.

The ethereal soundtrack of Placid Plastic Duck Simulator further elevates the experience to a spiritual level. Delicate melodies and soothing harmonies perfectly complement the mesmerizing visuals, amplifying the sense of peace and contemplation. The combination of visuals and audio creates a sensory masterpiece, leaving players in a state of blissful harmony.

In conclusion, Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is a groundbreaking masterpiece that defies the conventions of traditional gaming. Its lack of controls paradoxically grants players unparalleled freedom and immersion. This extraordinary game has taught me to appreciate the simplicity of existence, to find solace in the quiet moments, and to embrace the beauty that can be found in the mundane.

Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is not just a game; it is an experience that transcends the boundaries of virtual reality and seeps into the very fabric of our lives. I implore all who seek a transformative journey of introspection and serenity to embark on this remarkable adventure. It is an experience that will leave an indelible mark on your soul and remind you of the profound beauty that lies within the simplest of things.

I genuinely recommend this game, not only because I really like little ducks, but because its a [i]life saver[/i]. 

Like many people raising/caring for kids these days, it's a constant struggle to foster a healthy relationship with devices. It's really easy to just let a kid loose on a tablet, especially when you are tired or preoccupied. But as we've all seen, too much freedom/access can affect a kids social and emotional development. (iPad kids, Elsagate, Cocomelon, ect.). I struggled with getting my siblings to engage in activities off-devices or even listen to me talk when something is on in the background. 

[b] But in comes Placid Plastic Ducks! [/b]

Almost immediately after unwrapping gifts on Christmas, the kids wanted to go on their devices. Slightly hurt, and not about to let the expensive and thoughtful toys go to waste, we denied them. But yet again we arrived at the predicament; in 10 minutes they'd ask again or risk putting a movie on in the background that will steal their attention away. I struggle with keeping my attention on a given task and typically find something simple on in the background helps me tremendously. (A podcast, How its Made, ect.). PPD helped me a bunch, so why don't I try it with the kids?

Placid Plastic Ducks was an instant hit. With PPD on in the background and some music playing (not in game, sorry), the kids played with their toys all day. The next morning, while preparing breakfast, they begged me to turn the ducks back on and focus on the Submarine Duck or Impostor Duck. When they did get to go on devices, they were respectful when time was up and quickly found something else to do while watching ducks. I can't tell you how much of a relief it was to see this work so well. It has saved us so many headaches and tears. I buy each DLC immediately upon release and thoroughly enjoy the creativity and intrigue. 

Thank you turbolento, from me and my siblings! <3

Placid Plastic Duck Simulator takes gaming to new depths by immersing players in a charming, whimsical world filled with joy and laughter. As an avid gamer, I have had the pleasure of experiencing various genres and titles, but this unique simulator stands out as an extraordinary gem that captivates both the young and the young at heart.

From the moment you launch Placid Plastic Duck Simulator, you are greeted with a vibrant and visually stunning environment. The attention to detail is impeccable, with lush landscapes, crystal-clear ponds, and a sky painted with a spectrum of colors that will leave you in awe. It's an inviting world that beckons you to explore its secrets and embark on an unforgettable adventure.

The gameplay itself is as delightful as it gets. Controlling your plastic duck companion feels intuitive and smooth, allowing for seamless navigation through the waters. The simulator offers a wide range of activities and objectives to pursue. Whether it's a thrilling duck race, a friendly game of duckling soccer, or a tranquil fishing session, there's always something exciting to engage in.

One aspect that truly impressed me about Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is its clever use of physics. The water dynamics are incredibly realistic, creating an immersive experience as you glide through the ripples and waves. Watching the ducks interact with the environment, bobbing up and down with each passing wave, brought a genuine sense of authenticity to the gameplay.

The attention to detail extends beyond the visuals and physics, as the developers have crafted a delightful soundscape that enhances the overall immersion. From the gentle quacks of your feathered companions to the tranquil melodies that accompany your adventures, every auditory element serves to heighten the experience, creating a whimsical ambiance that's impossible to resist.

The replayability factor of Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is commendable. With a multitude of challenges, mini-games, and collectibles to discover, you'll find yourself returning to this virtual water wonderland time and time again. The developers have also nurtured an active community, regularly adding new content and engaging with players, ensuring that the game stays fresh and exciting.

Finally, it's worth mentioning the game's accessibility. Placid Plastic Duck Simulator offers a user-friendly interface, making it easy for gamers of all ages and skill levels to jump in and enjoy the experience. Whether you're a seasoned player or a casual enthusiast, the game caters to everyone's desires for an enchanting and stress-free escapade.

In conclusion, Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is a triumph in the world of gaming. It provides an enchanting, visually stunning, and highly immersive experience that will leave you grinning from ear to ear. The game's attention to detail, addictive gameplay, and overall charm make it an absolute delight for players of all ages. So, grab your virtual duck companion, dive into the waters, and prepare for a quacking good time you won't soon forget!

I like this game, it's super cute, and fun to look at. I love the idea behind it, and all the achievements and different styles of duck you can get. 
Downside? It makes my pc run way hotter than I'd like. I have a fairly young Razer laptop and it gets really toasty after about 15 minuets of running the game. Overwatch takes much longer to get just as warm. I imagine it runs so hot because of the graphics or amount of the quackers, but it is very discouraging, as I don't want my laptop acting like a space heater, and is the main reason I don't keep the game running on my second monitor all day. 
Otherwise a very wonderful way to pass time that I wish I could run more often. Because who doesn't love placid, plastic, ducks?
This game really makes you feel like a bubber duck

This Duck sim has brought a lot more joy than I expected.  Especially that my 2yr old son has been in my lap, every step of the way.  Kid always liked to just look at the rgb case, what was on the screen, etc.  Then PPDS shows up on the store page.
Fast forward a few weeks after purchase, and we now have a weekend routine where  he'll go running to my office yelling "Daaaaadddd THE DUCKS ARE HERE!!"
So we proceed to take the next hour eating pancake sticks, drinking juice, and calling out all the fancy duck colors and features.  The exact way I like to start the weekend.

This is an adorable game that's great for co-working streamers who want to have something in the background while being able to interact with their chat. I love the added secrets and mysteries that we have to solve; however I'd like to be able to interact with more objects. 

A big downside are the controls, but I understand why it was designed that way. I just wished it was easier to zoom in and out on a specific duck. Other than that, this is a great simple  game that's fun for everyone.
This is basically the best game of all time.

--- ORIGINAL
There's just something so compelling about watching a bunch of virtual ducks floating around, interacting with each other, and doing their zany antics. AFK camera mode while doing something you don't need to dedicate 100% attention to is a win.

Sadly there is no "Ducklocke Run" achievement for nicknaming all ducks... yet.

I thought this game couldn't get any better. Then you gave it multiplayer.

But seriously, for the price it's wonderful. It's a very silly little game but there's an almost hypnotic charm to watching the ducks idly bounce and bob along the water (or sink in some occasions). For the $2 price tag of the game I've EASILY gotten several hours of enjoyment out of watching the ducks go about their merry way. My friend has also continually sent me the new dlc each time it was released which just ever-expanded the amount of enjoyment.

If you're looking for a nice, simple, silly game to enjoy after a bad day, PPDS is absolutely a game to get, even if you're only getting the base game. I have absolutely fallen asleep to the ducks just existing and honestly? Best sleep ever tbh.
cured my depression

This is a UNITY game. About watching ruber ducks float on pools. With some cryptic easter egg. But mostly its a screensaver. So whats the problem? Its so simple yet the devs are lazy enough to sell the "game" without any video settings. So the game will make most gpus work harder than it should for a floating duck game. Its a cool game to keep running at night for example. But hell nah if your gpu is working at 100%.
So thats mainly the reason I dont recommend this game. There is no reason to not have video settings.

STILL NO VIDEO SETTINGS, but hey! they got plenty of time to make another DLC and grab your money!
This game is run by childish careless devs. Go place your money somewhere else.

It's very calming and funny at the same time! You can have it in the background and check in from time to time or look at them while working. So many ways to use your duckies!

The game is the absolute best cinematic masterpiece there is ever on the steam marketplace. The absolute and pure joy I get when seeing the beautiful characters fills me with ecstasy and the landscapes are astounding. The gameplay is relaxing, but not relaxing enough to make it boring. 11/10 Hope they continue to add more content into this fabulous game.
best. game. EVER. if you just came home from a long day of school/work, then this is PERFECT.

This game is surprisingly very well made despite you doing basically nothing, especially the visuals/lighting, it looks absolutely stunning. The OST is really good as well, and it would be really cool if you released it onto other platforms such as SoundCloud, Spotify, and Apple Music. My only complaint is that the panning/zooming can be very weird at times, with it seemingly happening on its own and making me zoom in right on a duck, making the experience uncomfortable. Otherwise its really good for what it is, and I would highly recommend it if you have a few dollars hanging around.

This game is beautiful in the most relaxing way possible.

For just $1.99, I got myself a simulator for watching rubber ducks float around a tropical pool with slides and shoots, with beautiful beachy sights all around, with cool vintage Mexican/Spanish Radio in the Background. I enjoyed my time playing this game, and it's now one of my favorite games of all time. I could watch these ducks for hours, I feel compelled to get in the tub with my rubber ducks for a nice bath. This game reminded me of how special rubber ducks are, and how much fun it is to see them floating.

While some would call this a "boring" game, I would say, that's correct, but a better term fort this, should be "Serene." I would love to have my own pool to watch ducks float around in. Now I have aspirations. Thank you Game Developers, I truly felt as placid as the game advertised. 10/10.

Note To Devs: Consider adding a bigger Beach in the background, and Putting a Giant Sand Castle on it with some seashells by the seashore. . Would love to see that in an update, as well as maybe controls for the ducks, maybe a push mechanic, though if you left it as it is, I would have no issue. Maybe consider creating a live desktop app that mimics the game. On top of this, maybe add more radio stations and the opportunities to tune the radio. That'd be pretty cool, but I did enjoy the vaporwave tunes, and the occasional Mexican Commercial. 

Thank you for this lovely game.

EDIT: Downloaded all of the DLCs as of 6-6-23. and it Tripled My Enjoyment. Disco Duck is my favorite. Thank you Again Game Devs.

for such a modest price you'd be a fool to miss this opportunity.

Watching plastic ducks float around is an activity that many people find relaxing and enjoyable. Watching them float in the water gives us a great opportunity to observe and appreciate their natural beauty and grace. The smooth, sleek, and elegant movement of the ducks is a sight to behold, and the way they swim gracefully through the water without any apparent concern or worry is a peaceful and relaxing sight for anyone who appreciates the simple beauty of nature and its creatures. Watching plastic ducks float around is a fantastic way to enjoy and appreciate the beauty of this simple and natural phenomenon. This game is a natural remedy for any problem.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead‚Äì murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time ‚Äì something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange ‚Äì uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" ‚Äì on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have
often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

After a long day of exhausting work, I can now finally come home and enjoy these fascinating ducks and spend some quality time playing Placid Plastic Duck Simulator with my friends.

One might think that this game would be like any other Simulator game out there. "It's just another idle game" or "why'd you waste money on this" is two common questions you or your friends might ask about this game. But trust me when I'm telling you that this game has it all! Action, surprises, advanced mechanics, easter eggs and now the obvious thing that perfects it all, the multiplayer function. Trust me when i say that you won't be disappointed.

Humans will pack bond with anything, so if you want to chill out while seeing if a duck you named Lester and a solo-mother duck you named Rachel ever meet in the pool for a blind date, then this game is for you. Also great for streamers as viewers can name ducks if you want, and it is an easy game to play while chatting with your fans. Quack quack!

Who knew a game about watching plastic ducks would suck so much time from you. While this has all the makings of a gag game, this game can be very relaxing to watch events play out as you collect an abundance of unique and creative rubber ducks in one of two pools. You have zero control of what happens in the pool as the physics, unique duck movements and interactive objects move your ducks around; you simply get to choose how you view the experience. Some random encounters and the ability to name each unique duck rounds out the experience. This is the kind of game for people that like to watch logs burn in campfires, honeybees, and similar experiences where you are a simple observer. It has enough charm and effort put in to be more than a simple Unity prank game. Buy depending on how much you enjoy watching things float in a pool.

Explaining Plastic Duck SIm in one sentence: It's a real-time screensaver.

There's more to it than that, but that is the very basic essence of it. There are mini events that randomly occur; planes fly by, curious little UFOs appear to steal a duck away into the night (this literally happened in the background as I was writing this section, thanks game), inflatable pool decorations get popped or knocked in depending on what your ducks do as they float around.

It is absolutely something you put on in the background/a second monitor, or if you want to have passive entertainment while doing something else. I fell asleep with it running, and as someone who has sleeping problems, it was nice to look over after a routine night of randomly waking up from poor sleep to see the ducks still bein' ducks without a care in the world, drifting around on my monitor.

Also a UFO came back and spat out a completely unrelated duck while I was typing this. Not sure what to make of that.

The music in the game is nice, although there's not a lot of it. You have probably ~20-30 minutes of music from the in-game radio that will loop. It's very good, but there isn't enough of it, even though it absolutely fits that mellow vibe of "yeah, the rest of the world kinda sucks, but we're just ducks enjoying what we got."

If you have an anxiety disorder, I can absolutely see this helping.

I never thought I would be someone who struggled with depression. I had a good upbringing, supportive family and friends, and a decent job. But despite all of that, I found myself feeling empty, unmotivated, and constantly tired. It was a struggle just to get out of bed each morning.

I tried therapy, medication, and even meditation, but nothing seemed to work. That was until I stumbled upon a game called Placid Plastic Duck Simulator. At first, I was skeptical. How could a game about plastic ducks possibly help with my depression? But I was desperate and willing to try anything.

As soon as I started playing, I was hooked. The premise of the game was simple ‚Äì you controlled a plastic duck in a pond there was something about the game that was so calming and peaceful. The sound of the water, the gentle movements of the duck, and the simple objectives all combined to create an environment that was almost meditative.

At first, I only played for a few minutes at a time, but as I became more engrossed in the game, I found myself playing for hours on end. It became my go-to activity whenever I was feeling down or anxious. Whenever I felt overwhelmed, I would pull up the game and immerse myself in the world of the plastic duck.

As I played, I noticed something changing within me. I was no longer consumed by negative thoughts or anxiety. Instead, I was focused on the game and the sense of accomplishment I felt when I collected a new duck. The game became a source of positive reinforcement, something I desperately needed in my life.

I also began to feel more connected to others through the game. I discovered an online community of players who shared tips and strategies for the game. We would chat about our experiences and bond over our shared love for Placid Plastic Duck Simulator. It was a sense of camaraderie I had not felt in a long time.

Over time, I began to realize that the game was not a cure for my depression, but rather a tool that helped me manage it. Playing Placid Plastic Duck Simulator did not erase my problems or magically make me happy, but it provided me with a respite from the daily struggle of depression. It gave me a sense of control, accomplishment, and connection.

Now, whenever I feel myself slipping back into a depressive episode, I know I can turn to Placid Plastic Duck Simulator for comfort. It is a reminder that there are moments of calm and joy in life, even when things seem bleak. And for that, I will always be grateful to the simple game about a plastic duck in a pond.

Ducks, ducks, ducks. (Played on Steam Deck)

While there have been a lot of idle games, where the goal is essentially to watch the game play it self for you, Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is somewhat one of a kind. 
It quite literally requires no action by the player, just sit there, and watch ducks. Oh hey another duck spawned. Oh this one has a propeller hat, look at him go fly away ducky!
There is nothing to really excuse my hrs on record playing the game, but I would say for the price, fantastic thing to have in the background while you work on other tasks, the chill beats, the ambient sounds, the random quacks as the camera zips from duck to duck, all with unique designs that make them appealing to watch float  in your pool. 
Oh there he goes down the slide, that is adorable!
Calling this a game is somewhat unfair, as its not trying to be. Almost all the achievements require no action from the player, nor is the player able to do anything other than move from spot to spot. Leave the game on long enough, and your achievement list will be full sooner or later.
The pool areas that are available are very beautiful, with lots of hidden details and random events that occur on both, somewhat guaranteeing you entertainment every time you glance back at the duck pool.
Oh my duck just got abducted by aliens. And they replaced it with an alien duck. Neat.

There is not really a point to anything you do here, and you can get some added dlc that is also very cheap, and has a lovely ammount of ducks, with unique mechanics and attention to detail leaving me satisfied with the pricing. But they do add up eventually in cost.
There is also the issue of lack of settings, the resolution being changed does not really help lower end systems, and having too many ducks can prove for a very lag filled experience, without the ability to lower the settings to compensate. 
With the unlocked ability to mess with the radio, I was also hoping for some more music variety, but I was sad to find out not really much else.
Some of the dlc has added some more active achievements, but they do not add up to much more than clicking on stuff. There are also some hidden... lore bits? Alternate reality game hints? That were fun to figure out, and I got a cool new duck for it!

Overall, It is a very fun idle experience to check back on while doing other things, the duck designs are fantastic, the interactions between them and the environment are full of attention to detail, with only a few minor flaws. Wonderful execution of the interactive screen saver concept.

3 weeks ago I was lucky enough to gaze upon the well renowned and incredibly sophisticated Machu Picchu on a visit to the stunning Andes Mountains in Peru. Whilst I stood high above the Urubamba River valley, below all I could do was merely attempt to take in the surrounding unmatched panoramic views and marvel at its intrinsically designed buildings and dry-stone walls, this was something I was sure would forever remain as the greatest sight the world could possibly hold. Other sites like the Effel Tower, City of Petra or even something as grand as the Taj Mahal whilst stunning in their own respective right just did not live up to such beauty and ingenuity nor made me feel anything like what I felt standing in that sacred Peruvian Valley. I truly felt that I would never feel this way again but recently have been lucky enough to have such a feeling reemerge from the depths of my consciousness when I was introduced to the peaceful but also strangely sorrowful world of Placid Duck Simulator.

Within a few minutes of game play everything in the world of Placid Plastic Duck Simulator was laid out before me yet the journey and better yet the destination still lay far beyond my vision and surrounded by a thick fog of what I could describe as a duck-less void or uncertainty. Yet despite this I always felt at ease, I may not have known what I was doing here or if I even had a purpose in this world in the first place but I somehow knew that everything would be alright regardless of what might happen on the journey I was about to depart on, a journey I might add I was anything but prepared for.
I would find myself peacefully exploring the depths of a suburban swimming pool at first only to thrust into the swirling unconscious grasp of a slide headed towards the unknown only then to find another duck waiting for me. What challenges I would be faced with I won't go into too much detail about as I truly believe this is a game you don't want spoiled but from fighting the chilling frozen weather above the mountains to even battling the forces of an extraterrestrial race from beyond our very own understanding of the universe itself I was never devoid of excitement and danger across my journey. The unchallenged sorrow I felt as I watched one of my most beloved ducks fall from atop of mountain to a almost certain death below still haunts my soul to this day as I could only watch helpless as they were tossed aside by the cruel hands of fate to a brutal demise. It is moments like these that truly make this game feel like so much more than just another piece of media and almost like a reflection world and its many experiences instead.

It is rare for critics like myself to find ourselves in a position where we struggle to find criticism of something that is to be reviewed whether it be a film, television series, food dish, etc as we owe so love finding and writing about it. More so seeing things that have flaws or are not perfect almost give us a feeling of superiority over them as highlighting ones weaknesses is often far easier than analysing their strengths and then learning from them as we as people often prefer to think of ourselves as already better than those around us and therefore not needing of improvement ourselves and instead more suited to picking out the faults we see in our surrounding environment that help reinforce this sense of perfection in our own lives. Yet the truth simply put is that all of these things we see in our everyday life are far more perfect then we give them credit for and the faults we see in them are often just a reflection of the faults from our own lives and selves that we have blinded ourselves from spotting.

Placid Plastic Duck Simulator showed me many things but best of all it showed me a reflection of myself flaws included and allowed me to find through an array of ducks that my destination whilst clouded never really mattered at all. It pointed out that my journey too simply put was not at all obvious and often spiraled out of control yet this didn't matter at all as what mattered was my effect on the ducks or people I met along the way. The destination was never reached on my journey but that never mattered for me as the ducks I met along the way made the journey worth all the more anyway. We may feel powerless to change our own course in life and often feel like we can't change the courses of others either but if I have learnt anything from the world of Placid Plastic Duck Simulator its that our course in life and journeys are constantly being written and evolving. They aren't just effecting our own lives but the lives of all those who surround us and sometimes bad things have to happen to some ducks (people) for good things to happen to others who at the time need it more.

I shall be watching the developer "turbolento games" closely in future and eagerly await what they attempt at applying themselves to next.

Once upon a time, I was a compulsive gambler. I would spend hours at the casino, pouring all my savings into the slot machines and roulette tables. I couldn't help myself - the rush of adrenaline that came with each bet was addictive, and I found myself unable to resist the lure of easy money.

My friends and family had tried to intervene, but nothing seemed to work. I was in deep, and I didn't see a way out.

That is, until I discovered the Placid Duck Simulator.

At first, I thought it was just another silly game - a simulation where you controlled a virtual duck floating on a serene pond. But as I played, something remarkable happened. I felt my anxiety levels start to drop. My heart rate slowed. And the more I played, the more relaxed and centered I felt.

I started playing the Placid Duck Simulator every day, instead of going to the casino. And slowly but surely, my addiction began to lose its hold on me.

As I continued to play, I found myself drawn to the calm, peaceful atmosphere of the game. I enjoyed watching the duck glide gracefully through the water, and listening to the soothing sounds of nature. And as I focused on the game, my mind became clearer and more focused.

Eventually, I was able to quit gambling altogether. I no longer felt the need for the rush of adrenaline that came with each bet. Instead, I found that the simple pleasures of life - like spending time with my family, or taking a walk in the park - were more than enough to bring me joy.

Looking back on my journey, I realize that the Placid Duck Simulator was more than just a game. It was a powerful tool that helped me overcome my addiction and find peace in my life. And for that, I will always be grateful.

This game is the greatest game since Seaman on the Dreamcast.  A true masterpiece far beyond games like Death Stranding and Elden Ring.  A must-have title with riveting gameplay, immersive graphics and a truly cinematic score.

In all seriousness, this game is a delightful idle game with nice (albeit strange) lo-fi music.  The charming visuals carry this game to a level far above its price point.  You just watch ducks fall into a pool and float around.  The diversity of duck that could drop at any moment as the meter fills creates an odd feeling of tension, followed by a rush of delight once it appears from nowhere.  It's the same feeling as a gatcha game, but without the monetary investment.  With all the DLC, there's nearly (if not more than) 100 ducks total, and seeing them all in the pool is quite the treat.

Some ducks have special interactions with each other.  The afro-touting duck will spin when near the disco ball duck at night, and so on.  These interactions help keep the game interesting, so I won't spoil too many of them.  There's also a bit of a mystery pertaining to the metal door in the background, and it's strange ties to 2 particular ducks...

Overall, this game has been great for my mental health and terrible for my productivity.  Highly recommend.

I am 27.
My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.
When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my ducks hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.
After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.
Having nothing better to do, I searched for a duck I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this duck and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the duck, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this duck a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the duck off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.
Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.
I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.
Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little duck helped me realize that.
Thank you

This game is fantastic. Just don't go into this expecting a grand AAA immersive adventure.

Because what you get is so much better.

OK, jokes and memey reviews aside, this game is legitimately really good for its price point. Based on the title and "beginning" of the game, you may think it's what it advertises itself as- a silly, funny little premise that you'll play for about half an hour and then get bored of. However, there are so many little events, secrets easter eggs, and interactions between the different types of Ducks that it's kind of amazing. Even outside of making up your own little stories and plots about what your Ducks do, there's still so much this game has to offer.

The music and graphics are also surprisingly great for how cheap the game is, and even without the DLC there are plenty of Ducks to scratch that itch to complete your collection. Yeah, you can always just AFK and leave the game running, but then you miss out on all out of nowhere things that can happen like [spoiler]having a UFO appear and drop an NVIDIA PC Duck into my pool.[/spoiler]

Ah, the Placid Plastic Duck Simulator. Quite a charming little game, isn't it? I must say, I was rather skeptical at first. Plastic ducks? How absurd! But after just a few minutes of gameplay, I was hooked.

The attention to detail in this game is simply quack-tastic. From the realistic feather textures to the authentic quacking sounds, it's as if you're really holding a plastic duck in your hand. And let's not forget the breathtaking scenery - the bathtub has never looked so picturesque.

But what truly sets this game apart is the sheer excitement of it all. Who knew that simulating the movements of a plastic duck could be so thrilling? I found myself on the edge of my seat, eagerly anticipating the next wave that would rock my little duckie vessel.

Overall, the Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is a delightful romp that is not to be missed. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or just a humble duck enthusiast, this game is sure to quack you up. 10/10

Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is the perfect thing for when you want to play a game, but you don't have the energy to play a game.

Often times when I get on my PC, I find a desire to play games, but after only about 10-15 minutes of playing I will run out of energy and either start severely tilting, or I will be unable to focus on a singular task for long enough to make any meaningful progress.
Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is actually genius in the way it fills the void created by that situation. As I watch it, I don't need to interact with the controls at all save for if I want to move the camera around, and even though I'm just letting the ducks fall where they may, no two experiences are ever the same, and as a result I still feel like I'm doing something.

In short: Good quack! Would recommend.

In the course of human existence, we come across experiences that shape our very being. We use these experiences to grow as creatures into something more; something better. This game about rubber (and several non-rubber) floating aimlessly in a pool is genuinely one of the most enjoyable experiences in my life. I could not recommend this enough. Expand your worldview, and embrace the ducks.

You've seen them in stores.  You've played with them in the bathtub.  You squeaked their squeakers.  Ernie can't bathe without one.  And now.....the ultimate experience.  See rubber duckies, as you've never seen the before.  Collect them all, and have an all-out quack quack rumble in the pool as they float aimlessly towards another pool, then back for more.  See them collide with each other in an epic battle of quacktastic proportions!  Take it to the next level and travel to the ice pool, where the ducks...go....wild!  Live the dream.  Quack on!

This game is a masterpiece, i have played 4 straight hours of this masterpiece of a video game and i can say that it was time well spent. I get so much enjoyment, getting new ducks, giving them, pretty silly names, then just watching them all interact in the pool, so much drama, so much conflict, so much emotion has been made from just the first pool map. it is amazing how a silly little game about plastic ducks can make you have so much enjoyment. I truly hope that the creators of this amazing video game, makes more DLC for it, there simply must be more ducks to collect, so much more for me to name silly names, and more hours to spend watching these goofy silly ducks, chilling in a pool. and yet, i still have yet to collect every plastic duck, i truly look forward in doing so, as i watch more ducks pile into the pool, interacting with each other in brand new ways i could never imagine. Thank you Placid Plastic Duck Simulator, this game is truly The game of the year. and i recommend that everyone, even if you are just thinking of buying this amazing game, to just buy it, its only around 2 dollars, and the dlc, which is not that much either!, and its just so worth it, everybody should be able to experience the awesomeness of this silly little video game.

Placid Plastic Duck Simulator is a unique video game that presents players with an experience unlike any other. It's a game that challenges the notion of what a video game should be, with its emphasis on minimalism and existential themes.

The game's dreamy 3D graphics and chill music set the stage for a tranquil and relaxing experience. The player is tasked with simply watching plastic ducks float around in various pools, while moving the camera around to explore different angles. There's no way to interact with the ducks, which may seem limiting at first, but ultimately drives home the game's themes of existentialism and the lack of control we have over the world around us.

The game's minor events, such as the two connected pools with a small height difference and the occasional slide that the ducks go down, add a sense of variety to the gameplay. But ultimately, the game is about accepting the lack of agency we have over the world, and finding peace in simply observing the ducks and their surroundings.

The custom types of ducks in the game each have different abilities and interact with each other in unique ways. However, players have to wait approximately five minutes for a new duck to spawn, which emphasizes the game's theme of patience and acceptance.

While Placid Plastic Duck Simulator may not be for everyone, it's a thought-provoking game that challenges players to consider their place in the world and the role they play in the grand scheme of things. It's a reminder that sometimes, it's okay to just sit back and observe, and that finding contentment in the world around us can be a source of profound peace and relaxation. This game is so good! It's exactly what it advertises. Very relaxing, chill, and a lot of amazing ducks. Some ducks have amusing quirks about them. But mostly they just float in the pool, and occasionally go down a slide. I got it on sale and spent $5.40 for the game and all the DLC and it was worth absolutely every penny. I highly recommend the DLC. Watching all the ducks would have been enough, but being able to name them too... it's perfect. One of my ducks was making eyes at one of the other ducks, and now I want a Plastic Duck Dating Simulator. But yes, if you're wondering if the reviews are ironic, imo, they are not. This game is genuinely great. My friends say I'm just easily amused, which may be true, but I feel sorry for those who are not.

Really nice graphics, I love rubber ducks so it is up my alley and it's a nice screensaver style "game" for a super cheap price. Watching a new duck enter the water is bound to get your Dopamine running even if just a little.
